As we approach the 2020-2021 school year, we know it will look different from any previous school year.
After receiving guidance from TEA, we have some clarity about our Instructional Delivery Options. TEA has given school districts very clear information about how we will offer instruction, take attendance, and, ultimately, how we will receive funding from the state. Your responses to the questions in this survey will help us make planning decisions. It gives us an idea of how to proceed in our decision-making for the fall semester. We will send you additional information at the beginning of August. At that time we will ask you to make a final decision about the Instructional Delivery Options you are choosing for your child/children.

Please assist us with planning for school in August by completing the survey using this link: https://forms.gle/cMn5yVqGfAeAGxqM7

Please respond by Sunday, July 19.
Thank you.

In response to Texas Governor Greg Abbott’s announcement on April 27, Devine ISD will reopen two of its athletic facilities with limited capacity on Friday, May 1.
Only the tennis complex and track will be opening on May 1 for public use. The public use of these facilities must meet the guidelines established by the Governor during his announcement of Executive Order-GA18.

- Groups walking or running together on the track must number four or less.
- The use of the football field is NOT allowed - participants utilizing Warhorse Stadium must remain on the track only.
- Groups using a tennis court must number four or less.
- The use of the tennis courts adjacent to one another is not allowed; please use the facility with at least one tennis court in between you and other playing groups to observe social distancing.
- The DISD baseball/softball complex will remain closed at this time.

The Governor plans to revisit the announced guidelines on May 18.

For your convenience, a computer lab at each campus will be available for you to complete the parent climate survey the night of Open House. The link will also be sent out via School Messenger.

Parents/Guardians,

If your child is running a temperature of 100.1 or greater or has signs and symptoms of flu such as body aches, chills, muscle pain, fatigue, coughing, difficulty breathing, sneezing, loss of appetite, headache, ear pain etc. please do not send them to school. Our district policy about when to keep your child home is as follows: Keep your child home with signs of severe illness, including fever (100.1 degrees or greater), difficulty breathing, irritability, extreme sleepiness, diarrhea, vomiting, mouth sores, and skin ulcers that are draining serous fluids,
Your child may return to school when there is no fever present for 24 hours without the use of fever reducers. Due to the increase in numbers of the flu in our area/schools, we are asking that you please help us in preventing our students from getting influenza or other illnesses and keep your child home if they show symptoms. Thank you very much for your cooperation with this matter.

The TEA letter states, "Due to ongoing issues and concerns with reporting, The Texas Education Agency (TEA) has requested that ETS conduct additional quality control checks and verifications to ensure that results for all students for which answer documents or online records were submitted are reported error-free and attributed to the correct campus and district. The Texas Education Agency apologizes for this delay and understands the significant inconvenience late reporting will cause students, parents, teachers, and school district personnel."

Once results arrive in district we will be mailing them home.
